title: How to Cut Insulation

steps.headline: Wear heavy gloves, protective goggles, and a dust mask.
steps.description: Most blanket rolls are made with fiberglass, which can cut skin and damage your eyes. Put on an airtight pair of protective goggles, and find some thick gloves that will protect your hands before handling the fiberglass. Wear a dust mask to keep your mouth covered while you work. If you have a respirator, wear that instead of the dust mask. While it isn't essential, it will offer better protection than a standard dust mask.

steps.headline: Set your insulation down in a well-ventilated area, preferably outside.
steps.description: Fiberglass is also a lung irritant. To avoid damaging your lungs, take your insulation roll to a well-ventilated area before you start to cut. Place your roll of insulation on a flat cutting surface.Tip: If you don't want to ruin the surface that you're going to be cutting on, put a sheet of plywood underneath your roll of insulation.

steps.headline: Place a spare piece of wood directly over the line that you want to cut.
steps.description: You only need the wood to function as a straight edge that holds weight evenly, so any spare piece works. Place your straight edge so that it lines up with the section that you want to cut. If you're insulating uncovered walls and just finished framing them, you should have plenty of 2 in × 4 in (5.1 cm × 10.2 cm) joists left over. One of these will work just fine.

steps.headline: Weigh down your straight edge to keep the insulation condensed.
steps.description: Insulation rolls are fluffy and designed to expand, which makes them difficult to cut if you can't push them down where you're cutting. If your insulation is on the ground, put your knee on top of the wood panel or joist. If you're working on a table, put your nondominant hand on top of your straight edge and press down hard.

steps.headline: Cut firmly along the straight edge with a retractable utility knife.
steps.description: Extend the blade on your utility knife so that you expose 2–4 inches (5.1–10.2 cm) of the blade. With the weight still placed on your straight edge, cut along the straight edge with your blade at a 45-degree angle. Drag the blade all the way through the bottom of the insulation and cut through your line. You can use a larger knife or machete if you don't have a retractable utility knife. Pull any loose fibers of chunks of insulation off with your gloved hand after you're done.

steps.headline: Trim in the place that you're installing it if you can use a joist as a straight edge.
steps.description: If you don't mind the possibility of knife marks on your exposed frame, you can cut the insulation while it's in the section of wall where you want to install it. To do this, fold it along the corner where you want it to fit by pressing it down into the 90-degree corner where your joist and wall meet. Hold the excess section in your nondominant hand and cut directly along the corner where the insulation is folded. Insulation is easily compressed, so err on the conservative side when cutting like this. You can always force a slightly bigger piece into a small section.

steps.headline: Place your foam insulation on a flat surface with a straight edge.
steps.description: Use a stable table or work surface with a flat edge. Place a cutting board or spare sheet of plywood down underneath the foam board if you don't want to damage it with your knife. You can wear thick construction gloves if you want to protect your hands while cutting.

steps.headline: Secure your foam board to the work surface with rubber clamps.
steps.description: If your board moves while you're cutting your line, you'll have trouble keeping your cut accurate. Place clamps around the edge of the work surface and the edge of your foam board and release them to clamp the foam board in place. If you don't have any clamps, you can weigh your foam board down with a sheet of plywood or a heavy object. If you're using something other than clamps to weigh your board down, use a flat object with an even weight distribution. If your item isn't flat, it may leave permanent indentations in your foam board.

steps.headline: Use a ruler as a straight edge and mark your cut.
steps.description: Put the end of your straight edge flush along an edge of the foam board and hold it in place with your nondominant hand. Take a permanent marker and draw a line along your straight edge for the entire length of your cut.

steps.headline: Score your marked line with a utility knife.
steps.description: Keep your straight edge flush against the line that you drew while you cut. Hold the knife firmly in your dominant hand and drag it against the side of your straight edge at a 45-degree angle. Cut halfway through the foam board to score it.Tip: You can tell that you've successfully cut halfway through the board by putting some light pressure on the section that you cut. If it gives a little or wobbles when you press on it, it's ready for snapping. You can use the corner of a putty knife if you don't have a good utility knife.

steps.headline: Move the section that you want to remove over the edge of your table.
steps.description: Remove the clamps and reposition your board so that the section you want to remove is dangling over the edge of your table or work surface. Place your board so that the line that you cut is 1–3 inches (2.5–7.6 cm) past the edge of your table.

steps.headline: Put pressure on one side of the board and snap the other section.
steps.description: Use your nondominant hand or a piece of plywood to weigh down the piece of foam board that you're going to use. Put your dominant hand on the edge of the section that you scored and push down hard. The excess section of foam board will snap right off, leaving a clean line along the edge that you scored. You can use your utility knife to cut off any bumps or rough edges along the line that you snapped.

steps.headline: Put on your protective eyewear and a dust mask.
steps.description: Spray foam insulation is made out of polyurethane. While it isn't toxic, the fumes can become irritating when it is cut so wear a dust mask. You're also going to shear off chunks with a power tool, which will send pieces of the material flying all over the place, so protect your eyes by wearing protective goggles. You can wear a respirator if you have one, but it isn't really necessary to get one just for this job.

steps.headline: Attach a serrated blade to a reciprocating hand saw.
steps.description: Unscrew the blade mechanism on your power saw by twisting it all the way to the left. Carefully remove the blade and replace it with a serrated blade of any size. Lock it into your saw by tightening the blade mechanism.Tip: Only cut spray foam after you've sprayed every wall that you need to insulate. Wait at least 1 hour before cutting it to let it fully dry. The longer the blade is, the easier time you'll have cutting large sections of spray foam off. The size of the teeth in your blade don't really matter. As long as there are ridges in the blade, it will cut through spray foam.

steps.headline: Stand next to the wall with both hands on the saw and turn it on low.
steps.description: Reciprocating power saws have two handles on them. One pulls the trigger, and the other helps guide the saw. Once you're standing directly in front of the section that you need to shave, hold both handles firmly and turn your saw on the lowest power setting. If you're using a corded saw you can wrap the cord around your forearm and flip it over your shoulder to keep it from getting in the way.

steps.headline: Start shaving the spray foam by running the blade parallel to the wall.
steps.description: You only want to remove pieces of spray foam that are sticking out past your joists so that your drywall sits flush when you install it. This means that you only need to cut the spray foam that's sticking out past the edges of your joists. Hold your saw blade up so that it is parallel to the exposed edge of your joists and slowly move it up and down across the wall to remove the foam. Since your saw will be running at the lowest power setting, you don't really need to worry about harming the joists if you bump them with your blade.
